Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research/RUI: Testing Hypotheses on Pillow Lava Production During Glaciovolcanic Eruptions
Award.AbstractNarration:
As recently witnessed during the 2010 Eyjafjallajokull eruption in Iceland, interactions between lava and ice can have devastating local and global implications. However, because these eruptions most frequently occur in remote, hard-to-access places, we do not fully understand many of the processes that can produce glaciovolcanic hazards from rapidly melting ice, such as floods and mudflows. In order to better understand the role of lava flow formation during eruptions within and beneath ice, we propose to study one of the products of subglacial eruptions, called 'pillow lavas'. Although pillow lavas are one of the most common types of lavas on the ocean floor, which covers about 70 percent of Earth's surface, their formation beneath ice is relatively unstudied. We are going to work in two areas with exceptionally well-exposed examples of glaciovolcanic pillow lavas in Iceland and British Columbia, Canada. Our work will help other scientists to better understand how heat is transferred from lava to water and ice during glaciovolcanic eruptions, which may lead to better methods for predicting the sizes of floods resulting from lava-ice interactions. Through our research, we will also have a better understanding of how to use pillow lavas from ancient deposits to unravel mysteries related to ice-age global climate. Finally, we hope that our data will also be useful for better understanding of the formation of the Earth's ocean floors, which may be important for future mineral and energy resources.

The main goals of this research are to use pillow lavas covering a range of basaltic compositions for testing hypotheses about the formation of subglacial pillow mounds, including models for lava transport within a growing pillow-dominated volcano and the potential for sudden transitions between explosive versus effusive eruption styles. Specifically we will address the following questions:
i) Is the initiation of pillow lava emplacement preceded by an explosive phase?
ii) How is lava distributed along and across the ridge structure?
iii) What are effusion rates during subglacial, pillow-dominated eruptions?
iv) Are multiple eruptive centers active along a fissure segment during a single eruptive episode?

We will pursue answers to these questions by using modern field and analytical techniques to document the three-dimensional structure, stratigraphy and geochemistry of two different pillow ridges with exceptional exposures: (1) open-pit rock quarries along a single fissure segment on the Reykjanes Peninsula in southwestern Iceland and (2) the crest of Pillow Ridge in northern British Columbia. Both locations have similar lithofacies, including a specific stratigraphic sequence of vitric tuff-breccia cut by dikes that feed pillow lava flows emplaced immediately above the tuff-breccias (TDP lithofacies association). We have established a broad-based research team, comprising US, Icelandic and Canadian scientists working in full collaboration with the PIs, to build a comprehensive database of subglacial pillow characteristics for comparison to pillow lavas produced in other environments and potentially to revise existing models for the construction of the pillow-dominated parts of subglacial volcanoes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to increase our understanding of what happens when a volcano erupts beneath ice (called ‘glaciovolcanism’). This type of volcanic eruption is important to understand for several reasons:

1)    They are dangerous – heat from the eruption can melt the surrounding ice [see Image 1] and lead to massive floods (called jokulhlaups), and explosions caused by contact between the hot lava and cold water [see Image 2] can make very small ash particles that can be transported great distances (100-1000’s of miles/km) and cause problems for global air traffic (remember the 2010 eruption of Eyjafjallajokull in Iceland);

2)    They make deposits of volcanic material that can be used to better understand ancient climate – special types of rocks (called ‘pillow lava’ because of their oval shape [Image 3] and ‘palagonitized tephra’ [Image 4]) form during glaciovolcanic eruptions, and they are records of where ancient ice deposits once existed that help test computer models that try to predict how climate has changed on Earth during the Ice Ages;

3)    They can help us understand volcanic eruptions in places that are more difficult to study – most of the ocean floor is covered by pillow lavas that erupted beneath the oceans, but these rocks are hard to study because they are beneath 2 miles/3.2 km of water while older glaciovolcanic deposits are now exposed onland in many places; ALSO we think that many of Mars’ volcanoes erupted beneath expanded martian ice caps, and those deposits are also relatively inaccessible (at least for now!).

 

Many things have been accomplished during this present research, including involvement of 16 undergraduate students from 6 different colleges, creation the first 3-D maps of pillow dominated glaciovolcanic ridges and a detailed geologic map [Image 5], generation the most extensive dataset of pillow lava size measurements and geochemical analyses for a glaciovolcano to date, production of estimates for the thickness of an ancient ice sheet that once covered the Reykjavik area of Iceland, creation of field guides accessible to the public for touring Undirhlður quarry and a ridgetop trail linking the two quarries studied in this research, and the determination that this type of glaciovolcano can have a much more complex eruption history than previously thought. The students all learned to do a wide variety of techniques that are critical for their continued scientific education (3 of the 16 are in or have completed advanced degrees) besides being practical skills that will help them in whatever future fields they pursue. Some learned how to make observations and measurements in the field, how to use a high precision Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver (very practical for all scientific fieldwork but also for surveying of construction projects, environmental assessments), how to use a Laser Range Finder (wide variety of jobs use laser distance technologies), how to create 3-D models of rock walls (critical for 3-D printing and manufacturing technologies as well as tracking changes to active mines), how to run sophisticated laboratory equipment used in scientific labs around the world but also used extensively in a wide range of industrial and high-tech manufacturing (X-ray Flourescence Spectrometry, Scanning Electron Microscopy), how to graphically analyze data, and how to write reports/theses/abstracts about their work. The results of this research have been shared publically through talks to local groups of Iceland scouts and at 5 different conferences in the United States, Canada, Austria, and Japan, and indirectly through the publication of the first book devoted entirely to glaciovolcanic eruptions (Glaciovolcanism on Earth and Mars, Cambridge University Press, 2016).
